myths.faultyLogicDescription:
Jumping to conclusions
Past climate change actually sends the opposite message than what the myth concludes.
myths.mythClaim:
Climate's changed before

Climate is always changing. We have had ice ages and warmer periods when alligators were found in Spitzbergen. Ice ages have occurred in a hundred thousand year cycle for the last 700 thousand years, and there have been previous periods that appear to have been warmer than the present despite CO2 levels being lower than they are now. More recently, we have had the medieval warm period and the little ice age. (from Richard Lindzen)
myths.mythRebuttal: Greenhouse gasses, principally CO2, have controlled most ancient climate changes. This time around humans are the cause, mainly by our CO2 emissions.

myths.faultyLogicDescription:
Cherry picking data
Looking at one region or a short period ignores the full picture.
myths.mythClaim:
It hasn't warmed since 1998.

For the years 1998-2005, temperature did not increase. This period coincides with society's continued pumping of more CO2 into the atmosphere. (from Bob Carter)
myths.mythRebuttal: Every part of the Earth's climate system has continued warming since 1998, with 2015 shattering temperature records.

myths.mythClaim:
There is no consensus

The Petition Project features over 31,000 scientists signing the petition stating "There is no convincing scientific evidence that human release of carbon dioxide will, in the forseeable future, cause catastrophic heating of the Earth's atmosphere ...". (from Petition Project)
myths.mythRebuttal: 97% of climate experts agree humans are causing global warming.

myths.faultyLogicDescription:
Cherry picking data
Ignores human fingerprints and recent period where sun and climate move in opposite directions.
myths.mythClaim:
It's the sun

"Over the past few hundred years, there has been a steady increase in the numbers of sunspots, at the time when the Earth has been getting warmer. The data suggests solar activity is influencing the global climate causing the world to get warmer." (from BBC)
myths.mythRebuttal: The sun's energy has decreased since the 1980s but the Earth keeps warming faster than before.

myths.faultyLogicDescription:
Jumping to conclusions
Just because measurements have uncertainty doesn't mean it's unknowable. The uncertainty is smaller than measured global warming.
myths.mythClaim:
"We found [U.S. weather] stations located next to the exhaust fans of air conditioning units, surrounded by asphalt parking lots and roads, on blistering-hot rooftops, and near sidewalks and buildings that absorb and radiate heat. We found 68 stations located at wastewater treatment plants, where the process of waste digestion causes temperatures to be higher than in surrounding areas.

In fact, we found that 89 percent of the stations – nearly 9 of every 10 – fail to meet the National Weather Service’s own siting requirements that stations must be 30 meters (about 100 feet) or more away from an artificial heating or radiating/reflecting heat source." (from Watts 2009)
myths.mythRebuttal: The warming trend is the same in rural and urban areas, measured by thermometers and satellites, and by natural thermometers.

myths.faultyLogicDescription:
Impossible Expectations
No model is perfect but they are useful tools that can reproduce the past and provide insights into the future.
myths.mythClaim: Models are unreliable. They are full of fudge factors that are fitted to the existing climate, so the models more or less agree with the observed data. But there is no reason to believe that the same fudge factors would give the right behaviour in a world with different chemistry, for example in a world with increased CO2 in the atmosphere.  (from Freeman Dyson)
myths.mythRebuttal: Models successfully reproduce temperatures since 1900 globally, by land, in the air and the ocean.

myths.mythClaim:
It's cooling

"In fact global warming has stopped and a cooling is beginning. No climate model has predicted a cooling of the Earth – quite the contrary. And this means that the projections of future climate are unreliable." (source: Henrik Svensmark)
myths.mythRebuttal: All the indicators show that global warming is still happening.

myths.faultyLogicDescription:
Cherry picking data
This focuses on a few good impacts of global warming but ignores the overwhelming number of bad impacts.
myths.mythClaim:
It's not bad

"By the way, if you’re going to vote for something, vote for warming. Less deaths due to cold, regions more habitable, larger crops, longer growing season. That’s good. Warming helps the poor." (from John MacArthur)
myths.mythRebuttal: Negative impacts of global warming on agriculture, health & environment far outweigh any positives.
